comment.text: This translation key is used to display a notification message indicating that a file will be moved to the trash on a specified date. It appears in the UI as a text element, typically in a dialog or information panel. The message informs users of an impending action related to expired files.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The word 'köçürüləcək' (will be moved) is not the most natural way to express 'moved to trash' in Azerbaijani. A more common and idiomatic phrasing would use a verb that directly relates to trash or garbage.
The word 'déplacé' (moved) doesn't quite capture the automatic nature of moving files to trash. A better translation would imply the files are being automatically moved.

The translation 'tiks pārvietots uz Atkritni' isn't the most natural or precise translation of 'will be moved to Trash'. 'Atkritni' generally refers to a physical trash can. A more accurate and common phrasing would be something like 'tiks izmests atkritumos' (will be thrown away in the trash) or 'tiks ievietots atkritumu kaudzē' (will be placed in the waste bin).

The Polish translation '{{date}} nastąpi przeniesienie do Kosza' is a literal translation that doesn't sound natural in Polish. It implies an action *will happen* instead of stating that the files *will be* moved.

The verb 'nastąpi' requires a subject. 'Zostaną' is the correct auxiliary verb to agree with the plural subject 'pliki' (files), although it's implied and not explicitly stated.  Using 'nastąpi' without a subject is grammatically awkward.

The Romanian translation uses the masculine singular form 'mutat' which implies the files being moved are masculine. Since 'files' is a collective noun and gender is not always clear, a more neutral phrasing would be better.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: {{date}} va fi mutată în Coșul de gunoi

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Sinhala translation "{{date}} කසළට යවා ඇත" literally translates to "{{date}} has been sent to trash." While understandable, a more natural phrasing for indicating a future action (as suggested by the English 'will be') would be "{{date}} කසළට යවනු ලැබේ" ({{date}} will be sent to trash). The present perfect tense used in the translation implies a completed action which doesn't match the English.
